Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Atomization-Based Cutting Fluid and CO2 Spray System for Machining Titanium Alloys

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The collaborative research to be conducted under this award is directed toward a more fundamental understanding of an atomized-based cutting fluid and carbon dioxide spray cooling and lubrication application system for machining of titanium alloys. The specific objectives are to: (i) establish an understanding of the film formation behavior on a stationary surface from the atomized cutting fluids, and its penetration characteristics at the cutting interface during titanium machining; (ii) better understand the temperature distribution and the heat removal characteristics throughout the cutting interface; (iii) study the effects of spray parameters, spray unit orientation angle, and fluid properties (for example, surface tension and viscosity) and the application of carbon dioxide as a droplet carrier gas on the machining performances including tool wear, cutting temperature, and chip formation. These objectives will be realized through the execution of three principal tasks: (1) model the film formation behavior of the atomized cutting fluid droplets and their penetration to the tool-chip interface; (2) predict the temperature distribution at the cutting interface under the atomized cutting fluid spray conditions; and (3) develop a process plan for an effective lubrication and cooling application during machining of titanium alloys. The validation of model predictions of the fluid film characteristics including film thickness and film pressure will be accomplished by employing the probe pressure sensors, and a high resolution camera. A hardware testbed will be developed at the site of collaborative partner, TechSolve, Inc., for the technology capability testing and evaluation.

The enhanced understanding of the tribological behavior of the atomized droplets at the tool/chip/work-piece interfaces will drive advances in tool design and manufacturing and improvement in other processes such as "minimum quantity lubricant" in grinding, machining and rolling. As the atomized-based cutting fluid spray system uses significantly small amount of electrical energy, this cooling system will help in saving electrical energy for those existing cooling techniques that operate a large fluid pump. Further, the use of carbon dioxide in this cutting fluid spray system can lead to developing many environmentally-friendly manufacturing processes. Efforts will be made to boost the participation of members from under-represented groups in this research by proactively participating in several on-campus/off-campus programs, including Women in Engineering Program and Minority Engineering Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major outcome of this research has been a fundamental understanding of formation, heat removal and lubrication mechanisms of a thin fluid film formed by an atomization-based cutting fluid spray system during macro-scale machining of titanium alloys. Results of experimental and modeling studies carried out as a part of this research have substantiated the phenomenon of fluid film penetration into the tool-chip cutting interface as a principal mechanism causing lower cutting forces, improved tool life and better surface finish. The numerical model of the ACF spray system consists of a spray model and a film-formation model and predicts ACF spray characteristics as well as the characteristics of the resulting film on a turning insert including film thickness and velocities. A thermal model is developed to predict the tool temperature distribution under the application of ACF spray coolant considering the phenomena of droplet impingement dynamics and film boiling of droplets. The model identifies boiling as one of the principal heat transfer mechanism that takes place during the ACF spray cooling and predicts a trend of decreasing temperature profiles away from the cutting edge similar to the experimentally measured data. It is observed that the ACF spray system of air-CO2 mixture prolongs tool life substantially as compared to conventional flood cooling methods during turning.

The experimental studies reveal that using a small amount of cutting fluid in ACF spray system, say, 1.5 mL/min, a significantly improvement can be obtained in the machining performance. The ACF spray system provides a cooling effect to keep the cutting temperature below 550 deg C. As a result, the carbide tool can survive longer without having significant tool wear. The ACF spray system has also been applied in end-milling of Ti-6Al-4V. It is seen that the cutting forces are influenced by the ACF spray system parameters and is able to extend the tool life as high as 75% over flood cooling when the feed/tooth and axial depth of cut values are chosen as 0.1 mm/tooth and 0.5 mm, respectively.  Further it is observed that the tool life increases by 50% when the droplet carrier gas is a mixture of air and CO2 as compared to the case where droplet carrier gas has only air. The enhanced cooling and lubrication capabilities of ACF spray system, due to thin film formation on the cutting edge are instrumental in reducing the tool flank wear and improving surface finish in end-milling of titanium alloy.

The results of this research have enabled the atomization-based cutting fluid (ACF) spray system as a more efficient alternative to the cooling processes currently used for machining difficult-to-cut materials including Ti-6AL-4V alloy. The small amount of cutting fluid used in machining with the ACF spray system saves both the cutting fluid (< 2% as compared to flood coolant) as well as electrical energy (10-30 W in comparison to 0.5 kW for a pump in flood coolant). The ACF system is environmentally friendly and makes use of the industrial byproduct gas, CO2 that will further help reducing the greenhouse effect. The spray system improves machining performances including tool life and reduced temperature of the tool. The fundamental knowledge that is being developed in this research on droplets spray behavior and fluid film formation can also impact various applications ranging from gasoline spray impingement inside a combustion chamber to paint sprays to cooling of electronic circuits. Furthermore, the use of CO2 in this atomized cutting fluid spray system can lead to developing environmentally-friendly manufacturing processes. The results of this research have been introduced as part of theoretical study and laboratory exercise in combined graduate/undergraduate courses, i.e., Computer–aided Manufacturing Systems and Micro-Manufacturing Processes and Automation, offered annually at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The physical and informational resources developed as a part of this project have been made a part of the Center for Machine Tools Systems Research Lab at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, where they can be accessed for future research and educational purposes.
